abstract: Jim Dwyer About New York column on Amanda Schachter and Alexander Levi, couple who have been building sculptural contraptions from junk on and near New York City's waterways; notes that the architectural firm partners began watershed project called Bronx River Crossing, which taught them the value of umbrella spokes as a building material and how two-liter bottles, empty of soda but full of air, can really become the pistons of an antigravity machine.
snippet: Things did not go as expected for a couple who built a sculptural contraption on the water.
lead_paragraph: Things did not go as expected for a couple who built a sculptural contraption on the water.

headline.main: In Story of Orb Marooned on Rikers Island, Trash to Beauty and Back Again
headline.print_headline: In Story of Orb Marooned on Rikers Island, Trash to Beauty and Back Again
headline.seo: For an Orb Marooned on Rikers Island, From Trash to Beauty and Back Again
